Poverty Category: Not applicable Objectives: The overall objective is to support the urban transport reforms undertaken by the City of Budapest and BKV. Specific objectives are to: (a) modernize and increase the commercial orientation of BKV; (b) implement a parking control policy; (c) decrease subsidies to BKV by reducing operating costs, increasing tariffs and separating noncore activities, and by introducing the private provision of public transport services; (d) contribute to the improvement of air quality in Budapest; and (e) establish a formal contractual relationship between BKV and the City of Budapest. Description: The project would consist of: (a) the replacement of 50 wom-out buses with low-polluting and energy-efficient substitutes; (b) the rehabilitation of about 47 km of womout tramway tracks and the purchase of track maintenance equipment; (c) the second phase of an automatic vehicle monitoring system; and (d) technical assistance and training in financial management, economic evaluation of projects, marketing, organization, and technical issues. Justification: Car ownership, traffic congestion, and air pollution are increasing rapidly in Budapest. Past subsidies, which Government can no longer afford, contributed to an uneconomically high level of services, ridership, and employment, while the financial constraints that followed contributed to the physical deterioration of the system. To address these issues, Budapest is introducing a parking management scheme, improving the coordination of urban transport services, introducing private transport services on a trial basis, and improving investment selection. BKV is also taking steps to increase its cost recovery, reduce fare evasion, improve operational performance, separate noncore activities, and contract out additional construction activities. The institutional improvements
 - ii - supported by the project are expected to reduce the cost of public and private transportation, and thereby increase real incomes. Risks: The greatest project risk is that BKV will fail to meet its cost recovery or operating ratio targets, resulting in a further deterioration of plant and operations. This could result from the failure of the Municipality to approve timely and sufficient tariff increases, or to provide an adequate level of subsidy. Experience in other countries demonstrates that maintenance deteriorates when public transport organizations have insufficient funds. However, the Municipality and BKV have already increased BKV's cost recovery from 19 percent in 1986 to 34 percent in 1994. They have provided assurances at all levels that they will take the necessary steps to meet the 50 percent cost recovery target by 2000. In addition, BKV is satisfactorily implementing their component of the Second Transport Sector Project and the EBRD Urban Transport Project. Financial risks are therefore considered to be acceptable. A second project risk is that the Municipality or BKV might proceed with a major uneconomic investment, thereby undermining financial capacity to pursue project and increase self financing. The project includes a covenant requiring the Municipality or BKV to demonstrate that all major new transport investments have an ERR of at least 10 percent.  HUNGARY BUDAPEST URBAN TRANSPORT PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT 1. URBAN TRANSPORT IN BUDAPEST A. Introduction 1.1 The evolution of Budapest and its urban transport needs mirrors the transition of the Hungarian economy. In terms of scale, Budapest accounts for about 20 percent of total Hungarian population and about 25 percent of all jobs, and therefore its management and finances are important national features. With the 1990 Self-Government Act, local governments now have clear jurisdiction over local infrastructure and services (including urban roads and public transport), together with the requisite fiscal and spending powers. Central government allocations to Budapest have been declining as a share of municipal resources to about 50 percent in 1994, indicating increasing reliance on local revenue and borrowing. Like the central government, Budapest is attempting to pursue policies which fmd the balance between economic growth and social development, protect the environment, tailor expenditures to fit available resources, and use public funds only when expected benefits exceed costs. 1.2 One of the most urgent short-term issues facing Budapest is the relative roles of mass transport services and the automobile. While mass transport predominates (currently 70 percent on a per trip basis), this is now changing as the result of economic restructuring, and the use of autos has doubled in the last 10 years. Until recently, mass transport fares were quite low, but now cover 34 percent of costs. Low fares and an extensive transit network explain why the usage of mass transport in Budapest has been one of the highest in the world. Subsidies to mass transport currently account for about 12 percent of the city's budget. Increased street congestion negatively affects the services and costs of public transport modes, and generates strong pressures for greater spending on road improvements. 1.3 Budapest is now pursuing a comprehensive approach to the provision, pricing and financing of mass transport. It is also Budapest's policy to slow down (and in some cases, arrest) the shift toward private cars; on the other hand, recognizing the link between economic growth and transport, it will also consider new road projects where justified. It is also the Municipality's strategy to both increase cost recovery from passengers and increase the efficiency of public transport modes. The Municipality is also committed to increasing the role of the market in the urban transport system, including privatization. 1.4 The Budapest Transport Company (BKV) operates all bus and rail-based public transport operations serving the city. It is, by and large, an efficient and relatively well-managed company, in the main stream of the European tradition, but burdened with the inheritances of
 - 2 - a command economy. Its fleet is inefficient and environmentally unsound. BKV is overstaffed (particularly in nonoperating departments), and it is relies on in-house capability for functions only remotely related to public transport. Starting in 1991, BKV has been using outside assistance to diagnose these issues and develop plans for future improvements. It is also the beneficiary of a small component (US$4.0 million) of the Second Transport Project (Loan 3032- HU, 1989, US$95 million) which has been effectively used to establish a traffic control system. The project will complement an ongoing EBRD Urban Transport Project which is being effectively implemented. B. The City, its Transport System and Institutions 1.5 With its slightly declining population of about 2 million people, Budapest's economy rests, in addition to commerce and administration, on heavy industry (locomotive, bus, and ship building), electrical machinery, food processing, and tourism. The River Danube divides the city into hilly Buda, with its historic district and lower-density residential developments, and Pest, built on a plain with a quasi-grid street pattern. The majority of non residential activities in the city occur in Pest. Concentrations of large-scale industrial public enterprises in the northern and southern suburbs line the Danube and reflecting the pattern established during the command economy system. New, private businesses are cropping up in smaller industrial parks, diffused throughout suburban districts. The construction of the outer ring road, now being carried out with Bank assistance, will no doubt affect industrial and commercial siting in the near future, and it may also reinforce housing developments on the fringes of the urban area. The growth of the city has been managed through a series of master plans; the most recent of these was adopted in 1988 and it is now being updated. Formerly, master plans were prepared by state-owned consulting institutions (UTIBER, UVATERV and others), but these are now breaking up and giving way to private consulting firms. 1.6 The Budapest capital region consists of 22 districts, each with its own locally elected mayor and assembly. There is also an umbrella city Government (Municipality), with an elected mayor and an assembly of 88 representatives; each district elects one representative, while the others are elected in a city wide vote, based on proportional representation. The previous Municipal Government was structured as a top-down hierarchy with authority for both planning and funding decisions; the new system is based on the 1990 Self-Government Act, which gave local Governments clear jurisdiction over local infrastructure and services (including urban roads and public transport), together with requisite fiscal and spending powers. In Budapest, the districts are responsible for primary and secondary education and some social programs, but the Municipality is responsible for public transport services and other area-wide systems (e.g. water and gas supply). The ownership of residential real estate was transferred from the state to the districts and the Municipality, and a divestiture process is underway.
 - 3 - 1.7 Personal mobility is high at 5.2 million trips per day and so is the share of trips taken using motorized modes, at 85 percent. In spite of the recent jump in car ownership, public transport still carries an impressive 70 percent of motorized trips. The fundamental approach to urban transport in Budapest, as in other capitals of Central/Eastern Europe, has been to give a primary role to public transport by providing extensive and frequent service at low fares. Budapest's Transport Company, BKV, is a large public-sector enterprise enjoying a virtual monopoly in the inner city; it has about 19,000 employees and a multi-modal fleet of about 3,600 vehicles. Longer-distance commuting and travel needs are served by Hungarian Railways (MAV) and the inter-city bus company (VOLANBUSZ), both also public-sector enterprises. Private sector activities are limited to taxis and minibuses. Bicycle ownership is relatively high, estimated at about 300,000 bicycles, but this mode is still limited to recreational use. Some 10 km of bike-only routes have been built in Budapest; these are mainly scattered around low- density areas, and the Municipality intends to integrate them into a coherent network. 1.8 The importance of public transport modes notwithstanding, car ownership in Budapest was fairly substantial in the past and has recently grown at a considerable rate. Starting at about 360,000 cars in 1985 (174 cars per 1,000 inhabitants), the fleet rose to about 472,000 in 1990 and is still growing at some 6-7 percent per annum. The current ownership rate, estimated to be around 290 per 1,000 inhabitants, is pushing Budapest into the same category as Western European cities such as Berlin (313 cars per 1,000) or Stockholm (249 cars per 1,000 inhabitants). This growth has not been due to an overall increase in incomes and wealth. Rather, the increase in car ownership is based on faster income growth for some social groups, primarily the emerging class of private entrepreneurs, as well as to easier access to secondhand western cars. 1.9 Despite the relatively high rate of car ownership, individual transport plays a modest role in Budapest. The availability of an excellent public transport system does not alone explain this phenomenon, since other constraints on automobile usage exist. The price of gasoline in Hungary has traditionally been high, much as elsewhere in Europe. In August 1994, the most frequently used 96-octane gasoline cost about HUF88 (US$0.85) per liter and diesel fuel cost HUF69 (US$0.66) per liter. The physical layout of Budapest has also restrained the use of private cars somewhat, the six Danube bridges are congested at peak hours, very few parking garages exist in the central business district and, as a matter of public policy, the Municipality has refused to add parking capacity indiscriminately. On-street pay parking has been implemented in limited areas, but this parking policy has been poorly enforced and improper car parking interferes with motorized vehicles and pedestrians. Finally, a comprehensive traffic management plan is in place in the inner city, on the Pest side of the river, and it will soon be extended. It features pedestrian-only streets and squares, a one-way circulation system designed to discourage cars from crossing certain areas, linked traffic lights acting as a gate system, pedestrian subways, and some off-street car parks, both surface and multi-story types. A similar approach has been used in the historic Castle District in Buda, with a strong focus on the protection of the natural environment and monuments.
 - 4 - 1.10 The road system of Budapest is extensive, comprising some 2,900 km of paved streets. The City spent about US$18 million in 1994 for road and bridge maintenance. Radial roads are better developed than ring roads. A single inner-city ring makes use of two out of six Danube bridges. Another ring road is in the making along Hungaria Blvd; it crosses the Danube in the north along Arpad bridge, but its southern crossing, the proposed Lagymanyos Bridge, is still under construction (see Map IBRD 25207R). The outer ring, MO, will be of motorway standard and will free Budapest of transit and some suburban traffic; 29 km has already been constructed. In addition to building new bridges, developing circular roads, and moving longer-distance traffic to new, higher-standard roads, major work will be necessary to eliminate 60 remaining railway at-grade crossings. C. The Finances of the Municipality of Budapest 1.11 Details on the financial sources available to the Municipality of Budapest, together with a summary of its cash receipts and expenditures for the years 1991 through 1993 and estimates for 1994, are shown in Annex 1. The Municipality's income as stated in forints increased by 32 percent from HUF57 billion to HUF75 billion during the period 1991-94. Inflation caused the dollar equivalents to decline from US$740 million in 1991 to US$728 million in 1994. In 1991, about 71 percent of total revenue was received from the central Government in the form of per capita allocations of taxes earnarked for local governments and targeted grants. The balance of about 29 percent consisted of local taxes, miscellaneous income collected directly by the Municipality, and loans. In 1994 central Government allocations provided about 50 percent of the City's resources, local taxes etc. provided about 34 percent and borrowing provided 16 percent or HUF 14.1 billion (US$137 million). About 41 percent of the Municipality's income is earmarked for special programs, e.g. social security payments, road construction, etc. with the remaining 59 percent available for expenditure at its own discretion. 1.12 In 1991, the Municipality spent about HUF48 billion on current operations; this amount represented about 87 percent of its total budget. One of the major items of current expenditure was the subsidy of HUFlO billion paid to BKV; this represented about 17 percent of the City's total budget. Capital expenditure was HUF7 billion, or about 13 percent of the total. There was a surplus of the 1991 operations of about 5 percent, or HUF3 billion. For 1994, current and other expenditure is estimated to be HUF65 billion, or 73 percent of the total budget, while that part of the current expenditure allocated to the BKV subsidy remained at HUFlO billion, which now would represent about 12 percent of the total. Capital investment at HUF24 billion is expected to account for the remaining 27 percent of expenditures. The Municipality achieved a surplus on the combined current and capital account of HUF7.2 billion for the three years 1991, 1992, and 1993, and broke even in 1994. 1.13 The Municipality's total borrowing as of 1993 was about HUF7.0 billion. During 1994 the Municipality signed a Loan Agreement with the EBRD for a loan of US$47 million
 -5 - equivalent which will be transferred to BKV in the form of a grant or equity contribution. In addition to the proposed Bank loan of US$38.0 million, the Municipality proposes to borrow in 1995 a loan of HUF8.5 billion (US$65 million) for 'Investments of State Importance". The debt service on the HUF8.5 billion loan will be financed directly by the Government and BKV will finance the debt service on the Bank loan. With the postponement of the Metro investment, no major borrowing program by the Municipality is foreseen in the immediate future. The Municipality is currently financially viable and the proposed project should enhance this viability by reducing the investment and operating support required by BKV. Loans for which the debt service is financed by other agencies will not be included in this calculation unless the debt service is in arrears. D. Budapest Transport Company (BKV) 1. 14 The Budapest Transport Company (BKV) was created in 1968 through unification of bus and rail-based operations serving the city, as a monopoly provider of public transport services. Its staff and assets still reflect the important function they were performing prior to the economic transformation. In 1987, the company had a staff of 24,600 and owned a multimodal fleet of about 3,800 vehicles. The deficits created by the policy of low fares were financed through a sophisticated system of operating subsidies provided by the City and the Government of Hungary. Major cracks in this system appeared when macro-economic constraints made the prospect of continuing subsidies (and thus a policy of low cost recovery) less and less feasible at their past levels. The first fare increase in BKV's history took place in 1985, the next one in 1989, and increases became annual thereafter. Traffic started to fall, because of fare increases, increased unemployment, BKV service reductions and rising car ownership and use. Starting in 1990, BKV sought outside assistance, financed through the Second Transport project, to study its organization and management with a view to reducing costs and improving services. The study, completed in 1991, indicated that BKV was obtaining satisfactory levels of productivity from vehicles and staff directly involved in operations, but its costs were high due to a plethora of staff in other departments (especially in administration) and its involvement in activities that had little or nothing to do with transport (eg. construction). BKV's buses were neither energy efficient nor environmentally friendly, and some of its rail-based infrastructure and fleet used obsolete technologies and needed to be replaced. The study also recommended that innovative sources of finance be developed to reduce BKV's reliance on city subsidies. 1.15 The first multi-party local elections were held in Budapest in 1990 and the Government of Hungary started disengaging itself from financing urban services. Currently its only remaining direct contribution to BKV's operations is compensation for concessionary fares. In December 1991, BKV became a budgetary agency of The City of Budapest, a temporary arrangement before its transformation into a city-owned company, operating under commercial
 -6 - law. A national law requires that the transformation process be completed by the end of 1996. In the meantime, the City is pressing BKV to reduce its operating costs. BKV's subsidy represented 13.6 percent of the Municipal budget in 1994. The company has undergone two management changes between 1991 and 1993 and has implemented a comprehensive reorganization scheme. Staff from central departments were redeployed in operational roles, 85 managerial positions were eliminated, and total staff was reduced from 22,000 permanent and 2,000 part-time employees to a total of 19,533; the eventual goal is to reach a total of 18,000 employees by 2000. BKV is also introducing a new accounting system (along EC guidelines) and making diverse, low-cost investments to modernize and improve its operations (e.g. automatic vehicle monitoring system, energy-supply management, vehicle priority at intersections), partly with assistance from the Second Transport Project. There has also been some increase in BKV's cost recovery (31 percent from farebox, 3 percent from other activities), although it is considered insufficient in view of the burden that BKV represents for the City's finances. BKV is further described in Annex 4. E. Key Problems and Issues 1.16 Five issues dominate the urban transport scene in Budapest. The first four involve BKV: (a) size of the service network and of the company; (b) fare policy and subsidies in a shrinking market; (c) aged and obsolete plant; and (d) formal status of BKV as an enterprise and its relationship with the Municipality. The fifth has to do with urban automobile policies. 1.17 BKV's network design was predicated on intense use of public transport, partly induced by very low fares. It also adopted a high level of service, in terms of frequency as well as of access to stops, not necessarily based on passenger demand. To support this network, BKV developed a very large organization, relying on in-house capability for most functions even remotely relevant to public transport. BKV is burdened by excess administrative staff, especially in non operational departments. In a declining demand situation, BKV's network is too large and the company is overstaffed. Meanwhile, despite significant fare increases over the last five years, the cost-recovery ratio is still low, and BKV's subsidy providers, the Hungary Government and the Municipality, are both facing severe budget constraints that prevent them from financing BKV at a level allowing proper renewal of its plant. BKV's fleet consists mainly of vehicles manufactured in Eastern Europe with high levels of noxious emissions, high fuel consumption, and obsolete technology. Furthermore, this fleet is aged, and frequent breakdown require a high percentage of spare vehicles, while the poor condition of tracks and track structures has brought major disruption to the tram network. The previous subsidy formulas were discontinued by the 1991 change of ownership and have been replaced by an open-ended subsidy with no incentives to increase productivity. BKV maintains an intermediate status that is not scheduled for change until 1996, and the current relationship between BKV and the Municipality needs to be improved. The proposed project addresses all of these issues.
 - 7 - 1.18 While the use of public transport services is declining, private car ownership has grown significantly, creating congestion and increasing pollution. The central business district (CBD) of Budapest was built before the automobile era; its narrow streets cannot accommodate traffic flows and parked cars obstruct traffic pedestrians. The resulting congestion has an especially negative impact on street-based public transport vehicles and pedestrians. It is essential that the existing traffic management activities of the Municipality, which focus on engineering measures, be extended to include pricing instruments as well. Congestion management through a rigorous parking policy is part of this project. Urban Transport Policy 1.19 The Urban Transport Policy of the Municipality of Budapest is designed to address several key issues. The major long-term urban transport policy objectives are to balance economic growth and social development measures and to protect the environment. In the short term, the City's main concern is how to slow down the loss of paying passengers to private car use. At negotiations, the borrower presented a synthesis of the City's Urban Transport Policy in a statement which is acceptable to the Bank and is included in Annex 2. The main features of the City's policies and action programs include: (1) Actions to improve the financial position and performance of Budapest Transport Company (BKV), through a combination of revenue increases, operational improvements and cost-reduction measures. Revenues will be increased through fare hikes, a new fare system and technology, fare unification to cover all metropolitan area operators, and action against fare evasion. Improved performance and reduced costs will be achieved through BKV plant modernization, increased priority measures for street-based mass transport vehicles, service network rationalization, adjustment of service standards to reflect demand, spinning off non operational functions, increased buying from the market, and better organization and management. (2) Pilot programs to test the potential of private sector participation in the delivery of mass transport services. (3) Actions to restrain vehicular automobile traffic in the inner city through a combination of traffic and parking management measures, including a new system of parking charges and better enforcement. The parking policy will charge car users for parking in the city center but convenient park-and-ride facilities will be provided in the outskirts. The introduction of road-user charges will also be explored at a later date. (4) Expansion and interconnection of pedestrian zones and a bicycle-lane network.
 - 8 - (5) Selected road development and rehabilitation to eliminate structural weaknesses in the arterial network. (6) Revision of the City's land use and transport strategy to reflect new economic and social parameters. (7) A comprehensive approach to urban transport finance, making use of new sources and modes of finance, including a link between net revenue from parking and public transport financing. (8) Improvements in the process of preparing, evaluating, budgeting and implementing new transport projects, notably introducing cost-benefit analysis in project selection. 1.20 In addition to the rehabilitation plan for BKV (partly financed by the EBRD and by the World Bank), the policy calls for new investments. The main road and bridge construction projects are listed in Annex 3. 1.21 The Municipality has also supported the establishment of a Budapest Transport Association (BTA), whose objective is to coordinate the providers of public transport in Budapest and to introduce a single-fare system. An agreement defining actions to be taken to establish BTA was signed in October 1993 between the Ministry of Transport, Telecommunications and Water Management, the Municipality of Budapest, BKV, MAV, and Volanbusz. A draft Deed of Association for the BTA has been prepared, and the unified fare system is planned to be introduced by January 1, 1997. At negotiations, the Municipality presented their Project Implementation Plan which is acceptable to the Bank (Annex 11), including a Municipal Action Plan which defines the steps for improving parking management and establishing a Budapest Transport Association. F. Bank Projects in the Sector and Lessons Learned 1.22 The First Transport Project (Loan 2557-HU, 1985, US$75 million) provided assistance to railways (MAV), to the roads system, including the construction of a 15 km section of the Budapest Ring Road (MO), and to a parastatal trucking company (Hungarocamion). It was completed satisfactorily, although the railway's financial performance was less than projected due to substantial traffic losses resulting from the economic restructuring. The Second Transport Project included follow-up assistance in the same three sectors plus a US$4.0 million component for BKV for a traffic control system. The latter was satisfactorily implemented and is now 100 percent committed and 90 percent disbursed. The road component is close to completion. The financial performance of MAV, and to a lesser extent Hungarocamion, deteriorated further during implementation of this second project for the same reasons listed above. In February
 1994 an agreement was reached with the Bank on a three-year business plan for MAV and an action plan for HC; but the situation is still deteriorating because of a continuing sharp decease in traffic and a failed attempt to reduce costs. The Roads Project (Loan 3549-HU, 1993, US$90 million) was declared effective on December 5, 1993 and is proceeding satisfactorily; the loan is more than one-third disbursed. 1.23 Project Completion Reports have been prepared Bankwide for about 15 urban transport projects or urban projects with significant transport components. Physical components were generally completed as planned and cost estimates were generally of the right order. All public transport companies made operational improvements. Institutional and policy initiatives were partly successful. For example, bus fares were successfully increased in Kuala Lumpur and to a lesser extent in Bombay and Madras, but not in Calcutta and Ivory Coast due to political interference. Past urban transport projects also demonstrate the importance of ensuring that there are sufficient funds for maintenance; this in turn depends on increasing cost recovery. 1.24 The main lessons learned from past Hungarian transport projects are: (a) the impact of economic transformation on public transport enterprises has been very large and has exceeded earlier expectations -- it must therefore be addressed by a commensurate action plan; (b) increased cost recovery is important, and related objectives and timing should be agreed up front; (c) training can have a rapid positive impact if it is linked to specific institutional objectives and related technical assistance; (d) technical specifications must be prepared early, so as not to delay the procurement process. These lessons have been taken into account in the design of this project. G. Rationale for Bank Involvement 1.25 Through early sector work and minor investments in the Second Transport Project, the Bank has been instrumental in helping BKV to perceive the need for change and to initiate its reorganization and streamlining process. This has already given positive results, including an increase in BKV's cost recovery, as discussed above. Other developments which affect public transport are taking place in Budapest -- the City Government, which unifies some 22 municipalities, is in the process of updating its long-term strategy for land use and transport, while taking steps to upgrade traffic, parking capacity, and management in the central area. 1.26 The proposed project is designed to pursue one of the key objectives of our country assistance strategy--namely to help raise the efficiency of social and economic infrastructure while opening sectors to private sector initiatives. This resulted in a 6 percent increase in BKV's gross fixed asset value and a 6 percent increase in the capitalization of the cost of major repairs, which then represented from 12 percent to 15 percent per annum of BKV's working expenses for the three years 1992-94. In the operating and financial environment prevalent in Western Europe and North America, evaluation of bus replacement proposals normally consists of life cycle cost calculations to determine an optimal replacement age for a batch of vehicles. If a new model of bus is considered, the differing capital, operating and maintenance costs, and expected lifetime of the old and new models are compared. Improved environmental characteristics, difficult to quantify but frequently mandated by law, may be considered, as well as the advantages of buying locally manufactured buses. The preparation of specifications and bid documents, and the bid evaluation process, is particularly important because new vehicles have a wide range of cost and performance possibilities. 2. In the case of BKV's bus fleet, financial constraints have prevented the enterprise from retiring and replacing vehicles in accordance with life cycle calculations. doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Budapest Urban Transport Project is to support the urban transport reforms undertaken by the City of Budapest and Budapest Transport Company (BKV). Specific objectives are to: 1) modernize and increase the commercial orientation of BKV; 2) implement a parking countrol policy; 3) decrease subsidies to BKV by reducing operating costs, increasing tariffs and separating noncore activities, and by introducing the private provision of public transport services; 4) contribute to the improvement of air quality in Budapest; and 5) establish a formal contractual relationship between BKV and the City of Budapest. The project will consist of: 1) the replacement of 50 worn-out buses with low-polluting and energy-efficient substitutes; 2) the rehabilitation of about 47 km of wornout tramway tracks and the purchase of track maintenance equipment; 3) the second phase of an automatic vehicle monitoring system; and 4) technical assistance and training in financial management, economic evaluation of projects, marketing, organization, and technical issues.
